author: cian riordan
content: I appreciate these sentiments. Some of us here have spent a good deal of time and invested a lot of knowledge into this community; it's a good feeling to know that the majority opinion is one that aligns with the spirit of @oaklandmatt's original foray into live-streaming with Jon. A lot of our work happens in the shadows and often goes unappreciated, but I sleep better at night knowing you guys are also out there -- in the weeds -- trying to set higher standards for both the creation and the consumption of music across the genres. Not everyone will get it and I think that's OK. We should do our best to be kind and welcoming to people walking into a now, 2+ year-old water-cooler chat, but we shouldn't also lower the bar that we've set for ourselves as record-makers (and thinkers). This place really is special, here's to many more years of community.

author: cian riordan
content: When I think somebody working at an intermediate level (I think of myself up until maybe 3-4 years ago) - that someone has at least a decade under their belt of working on music for myriad artists, many releases, many collaborators across a one or two sub genres. Having some chops as a mixer is a *great* start, now you have to build and maintain relationships, survive the ebb and flow of a freelance income, continue to improve upon your process and your work output.

author: cian riordan
content: @Zack Hames On second look, this comes off kind of jerk-ey and I didn't meant to just brush off your quest for saturation dominance! I guess what I meant to say is that through the dozens of interviews with Jon and Matt, it's clear that he's averse to using compressors and tends to use saturators more to do the job. While I fuckin' LOVE me some saturators, I honestly don't see the two as interchangeable... they're just two very different tools. One is leveling volume and the other is distorting a waveform to generate harmonics. I think saturators are a great next level tool for people who have wrapped their brains around compression.... but you really need some form of compression on an un-treated vocal. I feel in contemporary music, people are leaning too much on high-end saturation to get things to sound exciting and hyped. If I'm ever using saturators to distort things (which is often), I'm always trying to find some sort of un-distorted high end source to help the ears cling to clarity in the mix. Sometimes, things will distort in a way that will add this clarity -- or even manufacture it. But most of these multi-band saturators are just adding a layer of fuzz to the entire midrange up and the whole mix just ends up sounding hazy. IMO, a great example of modern hip-hop mixing is Mac Miller's Circles. The high end on that record sounds just as exciting as anything else, but it doesn't sound like everything got ran through a buzz saw (shoutout Greg Koller/Jon Brion). Just my 0.02.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I love this question. I had a folk duo called Anchor + Bell and used to play shows with Phoebe in LA! Of course so much of it depends on the production, and the genre is really rangey so don’t take any of this as gospel but:
1) be reallly conscious of where the  brightness is focused. Things don’t have to be darkEr than a pop record, but the top end might be focused a little lower. 
2) there can usually be a lot more bottom in the acoustic guitar and LV. That’ll really help with warmth. 
3) darker verbs > brighter delays

author: spectrummasters
content: If its any help, fwiw , imo It’s absolutely all about your gain structure and groups, and it’s kind of counter intuitive , you don’t want to be slamming anything ...just very careful db clipped here, db limited there ....across your buses . I have 6 group buses: . Kicks , 808/Bass , Drums , Music, Vox , FX and only clip by 1-2 db at the mixbus . Nothing clips by design or accident anywhere else .....for rnb/hip hop build your mix the Alex tumay / mixed by Ali way , get that 808 up first, on its own ....as loud as you want it , then build everything around it afterwards. Filtering is your friend. Have nothing in the low end but your bass. Overall I’d absolutely suggest watching Jon castelli mixing t Shine (he uses clipping well in there ) and mixed by Ali mixing YG , his mix balance and grouping is CHOICE. I say  somewhere between these two is the perfect rnb/hip hop mix lol . PS. I wouldn’t  do any of that edm/clip to zero stuff, it doesn’t work for anything other than serum madness.

author: Zakhiggins

@Ross Fortune getting back to you late about your question of what do you do when you don't know what to do, but, I actually have something that really works for me that I want to share with you. Its really simple and kinda fool proof, and almost always works for me if my head is in the right space. I've said it before in here but saying again. 

Litterally just sit in your chair, and listen to music of the genre you're mixing, for like a half hour

author: Juliette
content:
It is so so so rewarding to witness the progression of your mixes over the course of a several years. It's such a great way to show yourself that you are indeed learning how to navigate the soundscape, as well as remind yourself that you are getting better, slowly but surely.

When I first started, I used to watch and listen to hundreds of hours of podcasts and videos with all kinds of musicians and genres and engineers, and the words all sounded like total spaghetti. I got frustrated because I would mimic their EQ curve and my songs wouldn't sound good. It's quite nutty how your brain starts to pick up on those certain tidbits and figure out what's poking out, what sounds good to *you*, and so on. It's such an art form.

author: Mike Tierney
content: Damn we out here talkin about intonation systems? A lot of my bread and butter is contemporary classical/microtonal/experimental music and I'm in this world as both an engineer and often as a producer keeping track of how folks relate to the score and each other, take maps, etc. I tend to agree with some of the above that trying to chase down inharmonic relationships with EQ can make things worse, but I appreciate @LAPhill posting about bassoon/flute overtone series. @spectrummasters original question was about understanding the low mids and how they relate to EQing depending on the key; I think for me the way that understanding overtone series, tuning systems, and musical interactions in acoustic/orchestral instruments can relate to pop or rock mixing is like... Sometimes when I hear clashes between instruments playing thirds or clashes in the harmonic series and I'm trying to clear space in the mids/low mids, I do think about what instruments want to be occupying that space. So perhaps in the bassoon/flute example, I'd want the flute's fundamental to be stronger than the bassoon's first harmonic at C5, and that might look like EQing down the bassoon in the ranges of the flute's fundamentals, or in a rock mix looking at the bass's harmonics compared to where the lower range of the guitars are living. Obv instruments are moving and changing notes so none of this is surgical so much as the keys of the songs or the instruments' ranges might inform some general decisions about where to make space rather than just "cut 300 on the bass" or whatev

author: JustinLeu

Track level or group rides are the most transparent for me typically.

I have a lot of stem groups that feed my 2 bus and sometimes I will link a para comp on all of them and automate the blend during different sections, depends on the genre and overall loudness/density I am looking for.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’ve got some ideas for you. 
1) if your gain staging is done properly, you’ll notice when the low end starts to interact negatively with the rest of the frequency bands. 
2) reference reference reference. Listen to songs with the kind of low-end you’re looking for and reference them diligently.
3) have someone you trust that can tell you how it’s going when you think you’re getting close. I got a road rig together for mixing, expecting that I’d get 70% there before finishing in my studio. Surprisingly I got closer to 95% just using good techniques ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ 
4) its like anything else, the more you do it, the better you get at it. 

I hope this helps. Andrew Scheps is on headphones now and he seems to be real happy. You might be able to find some good insight from him.

Also keep in mind I do mostly Country Music and bedroom pop, which aren’t necessarily the most bass heavy genres.

author: Josh Bowman

To answer the original question- spec mixes are not uncommon, and often help when trying to break into a new market or even maybe genre. That being said the odds of it working in your favor are much greater in my experience when it’s the artist or client asking me to do one because they’re interested in me vs me instigating it.  I try to avoid them if they are “mix offs” unless it’s something way above my pay grade or that I love.

Curious how often others end up doing some form of spec mix? For me maybe a couple times a year at most but I’m not actively trying to get into those situations.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m not totally sure. I don’t think metering is going to help you. I’d avoid a mix by numbers approach. Maybe your monitoring needs some attention. A bad room can really make it painfully hard to make confident decisions that translate in the moment or even later in mixing.

Templates to me speed up your workflow not necessarily help you make better decisions if that makes sense. It’s like, setting up several busses you ALWAYS make, so instead of doing 100 keystrokes and commands to get your busses and FX built, two clicks and they’re there for you.

I don’t know what genre / style / level you’re working at, but I’d say just keep working at it. I love recording music because you can ALWAYS do it again. Time is the only thing you have to lose. With enough time, anything is possible. 

That said, looking at a frequency analyzer of a whole mix you like isn’t a horrible thing to do. Maybe you’ll see your mix is way too dark, or way too thin simply.

author: spectrummasters
content:
i hear ya , re: 808 through a neve pre-amp, spot on agree with you. thats exactly what i do ....defo the sauce  ! lol. I sum OTB and send my drums , vox , fx and music buses through my ssl sixes (no transformers, no phase shifting , lovely SSL punch and transient response) and then bass through the 73 and into the SSL on an insert return bypassing their pre....I came by that one from an old Jaycen Joshua tip ! 

I also find i use the neves transformers if ive got a phase issue between two parrallels, if i send one through the neve it can often shift the phase in one a bit and they blend better when they sum back after. This realisation led me into learning about phase rotation and all pass filters this year......im still deep diving phase since christmas lol 

I’d defo recommend SSl X-phase plug in to anyone ITB 

What you say about tape is interesting to me because.....

i wonder if the "to tape sound" will soon be a thing of the past even as an  aesthetic.....the artists in my genre, here in london and i know its the same in the states......their new forward looking aesthetic is this ruined/ultra smashed/clipped 808 , hi-passed percussion , serum synths and a  filtered vocal sound....ts like distorted nintendo on acid .....lol i actually like doing tracks like that for the madness of it....but magnetic flux and tape hysterisis are a v distant memory at that point me thinks......

Isn't the rub and dissonance what makes a reverb sound like a reverb? a 100* clean verb is essentially just a 'sustainer'. But seems odd to use it as a 'room' 'space' tool as it wont really sound like a space... i dunno just my thoughts.... but then again, i like dirty verbs. If i experience a bad rub, because of a reverb, it's often an arrangement issue tbh. Never heard a song on the radio and been like, 'man that rub in the verb, they should have reset the reverb for that part!'. 

-I'm not hating on it, i'm sure some people will find it useful for something. (Maybe a tinsy bit gimicky ;P )

author: Ross Fortune
content:
A question for people generally, but also specifically for @cian riordan as I know he rocks the 9-6 lifestyle I aspire to. 

How long does a mix take you?

I know this is a “how long is a piece of string” question, but let’s say an “average” number of tracks, a half decent arrangement you don’t have to wrestle with, with recordings that are largely good but could use a bit of love here and there. Essentially some kind of mythical median point job. This mythical job had already been prepped, with the back and forth for missing files etc already done.

We have the @futurejonaccounts of this world who can knock out 3 a day, but that’s probably genre dependent. I had the opportunity to intern under Alan Moulder at the start of my career, and his average was 1.5 days per. He worked on a NIN track and a modern rock album produced by Jackknife Lee during that time. The 1.5 days was pretty consistent. He said that to this day, he wakes up in the middle of the night trying to figure out how to solve some mix problem, then comes in the next day to sort that out and wrap it up.

The level rider seemed pretty good. And the compressor gets pumpy quick, but it was alright in small doses.

The doubler felt great and the two verb options sounded excellent, but I could see them being limited because they only have a dry/wet control.

Overall I like that it can act as an instant-vibe plugin for when you want to move quickly through a session. It’s got zero latency, which is great and seemed very light on CPU. But it’s not a fit for every style. Seemingly just for big pop stuff.

author: GaspardMurph
content:
In my experience they are quite used ! Many TV shows in France and Europe require TV tracks or PBOs (play back orchestra) as we call them here. A lot of newer developing artists don’t have budget for MDs that can prep a TV track, and aren’t very good with DAW to make it out of stems. Obviously this is very genre specific to variety / pop / hip hop. Most rock, indie, folk people don’t need these as these TV shows aren’t really part of their promo circuit. 

I have been called many times to deliver a new TV track with a specific timing edit if a specific program has a maximum length of day for example 2:20m.

I usually make the TV track this way:
- instrumental
- background vocals
- lead vocal throws 
- maybe lead vocal in on choruses minus 5/6 dbs

I have been advised by sound folks in TV / Radio not to master TV tracks. Something about loudness requirements, TV broadcast compressors and being able to mix the live vocals more easily with a less compressed and more dynamic TV track.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
Re: Limiter, to the extent that little micro-transients spike up post-compression, I see what happens if I shave them off a few dB w/ a limiter. Either it sounds better or it doesn't.

Re: 15dB, I really don't think it's a ton of gain reduction, assuming we're talking about a modern commercial genre of music. If it sounds bad, I'll back it off. Or if the producer hit it hard already, I won't hit it as hard on my end. Or maybe some songs call for a gentler approach. But I'm not gonna operate from a place of pre-emptive worry.

author: Josh Bowman
content: If it’s a modern/pop/“competitive” (ugh I hate that word but you know what I mean) genre how I deal with this in recent years is to make sure the arrangement is doing the heavy lifting instead of actual volume to get the feeling of dynamics, instead of making the song too dynamic (ie quiet parts too quiet). I always do a quiet listen or a headphone city walk to see if I loose important elements in the quiet bits to make sure I don’t overshoot the dynamics. Also don’t get stuck in a loop of just one section for too long. Also sometimes I start the intro a little louder and slowly let the volume settle to where I actually want it in the verse if I want it to actually be a bit more dynamic… just a subtle bump of the intro guitar/piano etc then let it settle under the vocal can help it appear loud enough in a playlist off the top and still let you have some contrast from verse to chorus. I know I said two conflicting things- depends on the arrangement

author: Zack Hames
content:
Something that’s helped me, especially with dense rock mixes, is recognizing all the frequency ranges add up;

So, how I use this, is I could do 2-4dB cuts around 1-2k in my guitars and overheads and room mics on drums, then suddenly I have a great little hole for vocals. And those elements all add up to enough 2k in the mix.

author: EliHeathMusic
content:
I’ve been thinking a lot about how I deal with resonance and unwanted harshness recently and would love to hear about how you all approach this (and maybe more broadly how you think about restraint and taste when using modern plugins). We have so many powerful tools at this point for cleaning up audio (eq, rx, soothe, spectral shaper, de-essing, etc) but when I listen closely to a lot of my favorite recordings from the last 70 years I’ll hear all sorts of weird resonances and abnormalities. 

Over time I’ve been getting better at finding a balance of how far to go with these tools and have also become aware of how easy it can be to go overboard sometimes. Beyond reps and intuition, are there things that have helped you hone in on this? And are you consciously adjusting your “threshold” based on the music or genre you’re working with or do you have a general taste for how you like to hear things regardless of the style and use other tools to get the character and vibe you’re going for.

In other words, do you think about how far you go with these tools as a creative and stylistic decision or more of a functional one?

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
Working on an indie pop mix at the moment that’s sounding a little clean and also a bit pokey with the transients. But otherwise it sounds good and I don’t want to add compression or clipping and squash the thing. 

I suppose I could saturate to my heart’s content but I wouldn’t mind going a bit weird with it instead and creating a parallel “everything” send before the mix bus with something like an echorec, echorec, space echo, or even a room emulator to add a bit of life into it, glue things together and give it a bit of a band-in-the-room feel. Does anyone have a way of doing this kind of thing that’s worked for them? I guess I’m kinda referencing Bleachers’ last two albums for that fun room vibe where it feels like everything is sitting in a unified yet slightly off-kilter space. I’m just mixing this one so I didn’t have the option of making those decisions at the tracking / production stage.

author: Sei046
content:
Guys something I’m struggling with lately is getting something to sit behind, lets say a vocal. Let’s say it’s a drum kit, stereo acoustics, bass etc. I’m struggling to maintain a solid and clear kit that doesn’t get in the way of a vocal in something like a country genre for example. 

If I want the snare good and bright and present but not seem like it’s at the same plane of the vocals. Transient control, room ambience, obviously pure level? 

Any thoughts on this? I suppose I’m talking about front to back depth but without making it seem too obvious. I see some guys using compression over the instrument buss that’s grabbing the instruments and holding them at a certain level and letting the vocal Poke above. I’d imagine this contrast in attacks would create that separation. 

Another example might be having a tambourine or shaker that inherently have a bright and transient nature that is also able to appear as if it’s not up front.

author: @lmmaudio
content: Man, interesting. I do the same gentle filtering about 3dB/oct on the high-end at 18k or so; but only on the Mid part of the signal and at the same time go additive eq on the Sides, but with dynamic mode. Normally on latin music styles like salsa, boleros and more traditional genres this move behaves very well opening the top end and preserving the sheen of the transients; which are normally a lot. Good to know I'm not the only one going with this approach.

author: nachomaquieira
content: It all depends on the recording, the genre, how much dynamic range it needs, and whether it's competing with other elements. When I’m going for something transparent, I usually go with the ToneProjects Unisum on the insert, hitting just the louder peaks very gently, 1, 2, 3dB max. Then I add a subtle parallel comp (just as much as it helps) using something more aggressive, the SSL G Bus Comp often works great for that, also like the la2a if a slowerish releases fits into the song.

author: Chris Lyon
content:
From my experience, if you focus it on low mids rather than harsh unpleasant frequencies while sidechaining, it can make room for the body of vocals or important instruments to cut through.

A lot of the time, those resonances are the defining characteristics of each sound so side chaining even to harsh high-mid info can allow the character of a focus track to cut while limiting the stacking of those possibly harsh frequencies with other tracks. 

Experiment with the sidechain in mid/side unlinked and you can get more aggressive with sidechaining the lead vocal to the instrumental. In a dense pop mix, it can be a lifesaver.
